title: Ruth Chapter 4 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ruth chapter 4 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ruth Chapter 4 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ruth Chapter 4.

questions.question: Where did Boaz sit down to meet the kinsman?
questions.correctAnswer: At the gate
questions.explanation: Boaz went up to the gate and sat down there to meet the kinsman, as stated in Ruth 4:1.

questions.question: How many elders did Boaz take with him to the gate?
questions.correctAnswer: Ten
questions.explanation: Boaz took ten men of the elders of the city to sit with him at the gate according to Ruth 4:2.

questions.question: What was Naomi selling?
questions.correctAnswer: A parcel of land
questions.explanation: Naomi was selling a parcel of land that belonged to their brother Elimelech, as mentioned in Ruth 4:3.

questions.question: What did Boaz ask the kinsman to do if he wanted to redeem the land?
options: Redeem it before the inhabitants and elders
questions.correctAnswer: Redeem it before the inhabitants and elders
questions.explanation: Boaz told the kinsman to buy the land before the inhabitants and elders if he intended to redeem it as seen in Ruth 4:4.

questions.question: Who was Ruth to Boaz after he purchased the land?
questions.correctAnswer: His wife
questions.explanation: Boaz declared that he had purchased Ruth to be his wife, as recorded in Ruth 4:10.

questions.question: What did the kinsman do to show he could not redeem the land himself?
questions.correctAnswer: He plucked off his shoe
questions.explanation: The kinsman took off his shoe to confirm the transaction, a custom in Israel for redeeming property, as described in Ruth 4:7-8.

questions.question: Who did Boaz say he purchased the land from?
questions.correctAnswer: Naomi
questions.explanation: Boaz stated he bought all that belonged to Elimelech from the hand of Naomi in Ruth 4:9.

questions.question: According to the people at the gate, who did they compare Ruth to?
questions.correctAnswer: Rachel and Leah
questions.explanation: The people compared Ruth to Rachel and Leah, who built the house of Israel, as in Ruth 4:11.

questions.question: Who was the son born to Ruth and Boaz?
questions.correctAnswer: Obed
questions.explanation: The child born to Ruth and Boaz was named Obed, as stated in Ruth 4:17.

questions.question: True or False: Boaz sat down at the gate to speak to the kinsman before the elders arrived.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Boaz sat at the gate and first spoke to the kinsman before involving the elders, according to Ruth 4:1-2.

questions.question: True or False: The kinsman agreed to redeem the land and also marry Ruth.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The kinsman agreed to redeem the land but declined to marry Ruth to avoid harming his own inheritance, as in Ruth 4:6.

questions.question: True or False: The women of the town blessed Naomi for having a kinsman-redeemer.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The women said, 'Blessed be the LORD, which hath not left thee this day without a kinsman,' as recorded in Ruth 4:14.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Ruth 4:13: 'So Boaz took Ruth, and she was his wife: and when he went in unto her, the LORD gave her ______, and she bare a son.'
questions.correctAnswer: conception
questions.explanation: The verse states the LORD gave Ruth conception, leading to the birth of a son, according to Ruth 4:13.

questions.question: What did Naomi do with the child Obed?
options: Took him and laid him in her bosom
Brought him to the city gate
questions.correctAnswer: Took him and laid him in her bosom
questions.explanation: Naomi took the child and laid him in her bosom and became nurse to him, as described in Ruth 4:16.

questions.question: Who was Obed the father of?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesse
questions.explanation: Obed was the father of Jesse, as mentioned in Ruth 4:17.

medium.title: Ruth Chapter 4 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ruth Chapter 4 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Ruth 4 teach us about integrity and honesty in business dealings?
options: Boaz openly declares the transaction before the elders and witnesses
Boaz hides the transaction from the community
Boaz forces the kinsman to buy the land
Boaz refuses to involve the city elders
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz openly declares the transaction before the elders and witnesses
questions.explanation: Boaz ensures the transaction is public by summoning ten elders and witnesses at the city gate (Ruth 4:2, 4:9). This demonstrates honesty and transparency.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God's provision during difficult times. Based on Ruth 4, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God provides through faithful obedience and trusting relationships
God will always remove all hardships immediately
We must rely only on our own strength
God's provision is random and uncertain
questions.correctAnswer: God provides through faithful obedience and trusting relationships
questions.explanation: Ruth and Boaz’s story shows God’s provision through Ruth’s faithfulness and Boaz’s willingness to redeem (Ruth 4:4, 4:13, 4:14). Trusting God and acting obediently leads to blessings.

questions.question: What does the custom of removing a shoe symbolize in Ruth 4 regarding commitments and agreements?
options: It serves as a public testimony to confirm the redemption agreement
It is a sign of disrespect to the other party
It means the buyer refuses to redeem
It indicates the transaction is secret
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as a public testimony to confirm the redemption agreement
questions.explanation: Verse Ruth 4:7 explains that removing a shoe was a legal custom in Israel to confirm a transaction publicly, symbolizing commitment and testimony.

questions.question: How does Ruth 4 illustrate the importance of family and legacy in Christian living?
options: Boaz marries Ruth to raise up the name of the deceased, preserving family inheritance
Family legacy is unimportant in God's plan
Only personal success matters, not family
Legacy is only about wealth accumulation
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz marries Ruth to raise up the name of the deceased, preserving family inheritance
questions.explanation: Boaz redeems Ruth and marries her to preserve Mahlon’s family line, showing the value of honoring family and legacy (Ruth 4:5, 4:10).

questions.question: What spiritual lesson about humility and contentment can we learn from the kinsman’s response to redeem the land?
options: He declines to redeem to avoid harming his own inheritance
He tries to take more than he should
questions.correctAnswer: He declines to redeem to avoid harming his own inheritance
questions.explanation: The kinsman humbly refuses redemption to avoid damaging his own estate (Ruth 4:6), illustrating contentment and responsible stewardship.

questions.question: How does Ruth 4 teach about the role of the community and church in supporting families?
options: The elders and people act as witnesses and bless the marriage and family
Only the head of the family matters
questions.correctAnswer: The elders and people act as witnesses and bless the marriage and family
questions.explanation: The city elders and people witness Boaz’s redemption and bless Ruth and Naomi, showing communal support in family and covenant matters (Ruth 4:2, 4:11).

questions.question: How does this chapter illustrate perseverance and faithfulness during trials?
options: Ruth remains loyal to Naomi and trusts God's plan despite hardship
Ruth abandons Naomi in hard times
Ruth relies on her own strength alone
questions.correctAnswer: Ruth remains loyal to Naomi and trusts God's plan despite hardship
questions.explanation: Throughout Ruth 4, Ruth’s faithfulness and loyalty to Naomi lead to God’s blessing, demonstrating perseverance through trials (Ruth 4:13-15).

questions.question: True or False: Boaz’s action of redeeming Ruth was motivated by love and a desire to honor God’s law.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Boaz redeems Ruth to raise up the name of the dead and preserve the inheritance, acting out of love and obedience to God's law (Ruth 4:5, 4:10).

questions.question: True or False: Naomi was left without hope or family support at the end of Ruth 4.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Naomi receives a kinsman-redeemer through Boaz and Ruth, and the child Obed brings restoration and hope (Ruth 4:14-17).

questions.question: How does Ruth 4 emphasize the importance of prayer and blessing in family life?
options: The people bless Ruth and Boaz’s marriage, asking God for prosperity
No blessings or prayers are mentioned
questions.correctAnswer: The people bless Ruth and Boaz’s marriage, asking God for prosperity
questions.explanation: The elders and people pray blessings on Ruth and Boaz, likening Ruth to Rachel and Leah, which highlights the role of prayer and blessing in family life (Ruth 4:11-12).

questions.question: A believer is facing uncertainty about their family legacy. Based on Ruth 4, what biblical principle can encourage them?
options: God can raise up a legacy through unexpected people and circumstances
Family legacy depends solely on human effort
Legacy is unimportant in God's kingdom
Only wealthy families have a legacy
questions.correctAnswer: God can raise up a legacy through unexpected people and circumstances
questions.explanation: Ruth, a Moabitess, becomes part of the lineage of David, showing God’s sovereign ability to establish a legacy in surprising ways (Ruth 4:17, 4:21-22).

questions.question: What does the chapter teach about generosity and stewardship through Boaz’s actions?
options: Boaz generously redeems the land and marries Ruth to protect the family inheritance
Boaz refuses to help Ruth and Naomi
Boaz only acts for his own gain
Boaz ignores the needs of others
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz generously redeems the land and marries Ruth to protect the family inheritance
questions.explanation: Boaz’s willingness to redeem Naomi’s land and marry Ruth reflects generosity and faithful stewardship of family and property (Ruth 4:4-10).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Naomi took the child, laid it in her bosom, and became ________ unto it.
questions.correctAnswer: nurse
questions.explanation: Ruth 4:16 states Naomi took the child and became nurse to it, showing care and nurturing within family life.

questions.question: How does Ruth 4 encourage believers to be witnesses and uphold community accountability?
options: Boaz calls elders and witnesses to confirm agreements publicly
Transactions are done secretly without witnesses
Community does not get involved in personal matters
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz calls elders and witnesses to confirm agreements publicly
questions.explanation: Boaz involves ten elders and all people at the gate to witness the redemption, emphasizing accountability and community involvement (Ruth 4:2, 4:9).

questions.question: When Boaz marries Ruth, what blessing does the Lord give her, illustrating God’s faithfulness in family life?
options: The Lord gave her conception and she bore a son
The Lord made her wealthy immediately
The Lord gave her many servants
The Lord removed all trials instantly
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord gave her conception and she bore a son
questions.explanation: Ruth 4:13 states that after marriage, the Lord blessed Ruth with a son, demonstrating God’s faithfulness to bless families.

hard.title: Ruth Chapter 4 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ruth Chapter 4.

questions.question: What legal custom is described in Ruth 4:7 that confirmed transactions in Israel?
options: A man plucked off his shoe and gave it to his neighbor
A man shook hands with the elders
A man gave a piece of cloth as a token
A man poured wine to seal the deal
questions.correctAnswer: A man plucked off his shoe and gave it to his neighbor
questions.explanation: Ruth 4:7 describes the ancient Israelite custom where a man plucked off his shoe and gave it to his neighbor as a testimony to confirm a redemption or exchange.

questions.question: In Ruth 4:4, what was Boaz's approach to the kinsman-redeemer regarding the land of Elimelech?
options: Boaz invited him to buy the land before the elders and inhabitants
Boaz demanded immediate purchase of the land
Boaz asked him to wait until the harvest to decide
Boaz told him to sell the land to a stranger
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz invited him to buy the land before the elders and inhabitants
questions.explanation: Boaz told the kinsman that Naomi was selling Elimelech's land and invited him to redeem it publicly before the elders and inhabitants (Ruth 4:4).

questions.question: Who did Boaz purchase to be his wife according to Ruth 4:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Ruth the Moabitess
questions.explanation: Boaz declares he has purchased Ruth the Moabitess, wife of Mahlon, to raise up the name of the dead on his inheritance (Ruth 4:10).

questions.question: What was the significance of Boaz marrying Ruth as stated in Ruth 4:10?
options: To raise up the name of the dead upon his inheritance
To establish a new covenant with Moab
To gain political power in Bethlehem
To fulfill the law of first fruits
questions.correctAnswer: To raise up the name of the dead upon his inheritance
questions.explanation: Boaz's marriage to Ruth was to raise up the name of Mahlon, the dead husband, ensuring his inheritance and name were preserved (Ruth 4:10).

questions.question: Which two matriarchs does the people in Ruth 4:11 compare Ruth to?
questions.correctAnswer: Rachel and Leah
questions.explanation: The elders and people bless Ruth by comparing her to Rachel and Leah, who built the house of Israel (Ruth 4:11).

questions.question: What does the genealogy at the end of Ruth 4 (verses 18-22) illustrate about Boaz?
options: He is part of the lineage leading to King David
He is a descendant of Moses
He is from the tribe of Levi
He is the firstborn of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: He is part of the lineage leading to King David
questions.explanation: The genealogy traces from Pharez down to David, showing Boaz as an ancestor of King David (Ruth 4:18-22).

questions.question: According to Ruth 4:6, why did the nearer kinsman refuse to redeem the land?
options: He feared it would mar his own inheritance
He did not have enough money
He was not interested in marriage
He was from a different tribe
questions.correctAnswer: He feared it would mar his own inheritance
questions.explanation: The kinsman said he could not redeem it because it might damage his own inheritance (Ruth 4:6).

questions.question: What role do the elders of the city play in the events of Ruth 4?
options: They witness and confirm the redemption and marriage
They decide who will be the kinsman-redeemer
questions.correctAnswer: They witness and confirm the redemption and marriage
questions.explanation: Boaz gathers ten elders to witness the redemption of the land and his marriage to Ruth, giving legal and communal confirmation (Ruth 4:2, 4:9-11).

questions.question: The naming of Obed in Ruth 4:17 foreshadows which significant biblical figure?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Obed is identified as the father of Jesse, who is the father of David, foreshadowing the Davidic lineage (Ruth 4:17).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Ruth 4:13, the LORD gave Ruth ________ after she became Boaz's wife.
questions.correctAnswer: conception
questions.explanation: The verse states that after Boaz and Ruth were married, the LORD gave her conception, and she bore a son (Ruth 4:13).

questions.question: True or False: According to Ruth 4:15, Naomi considered Ruth to be better to her than seven sons.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ruth 4:15 explicitly states that Ruth, who loved Naomi, was better to her than seven sons.

questions.question: What does Boaz’s act of removing his shoe symbolize in Ruth 4:8 within the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: A formal renunciation of the right to redeem
questions.correctAnswer: A formal renunciation of the right to redeem
questions.explanation: Removing the shoe was a customary way to formally relinquish the right to redeem property, as explained in Ruth 4:7-8.

questions.question: How does the theme of redemption in Ruth 4 connect with the broader biblical theme of kinsman-redeemer found in Leviticus and Deuteronomy?
options: Boaz acting as a kinsman-redeemer parallels the mandate to redeem family property and preserve lineage
It contradicts the laws by marrying a foreigner
It introduces a new covenant unrelated to the law
It primarily focuses on wealth accumulation
questions.correctAnswer: Boaz acting as a kinsman-redeemer parallels the mandate to redeem family property and preserve lineage
questions.explanation: Boaz's redemption of land and marriage to Ruth fulfills the Levitical law about kinsman-redeemers preserving family inheritance and name (Ruth 4:4-5; see Leviticus 25:25-28).

questions.question: In Ruth 4:12, the blessing references the house of Pharez. What is the significance of Pharez in Israel's history?
options: Pharez is an ancestor of King David, linking Ruth’s offspring to Israel’s royal line
Pharez was a judge of Israel
Pharez led the Israelites into the Promised Land
Pharez was a prophet in Bethlehem
questions.correctAnswer: Pharez is an ancestor of King David, linking Ruth’s offspring to Israel’s royal line
questions.explanation: Pharez, born of Tamar and Judah, is a key ancestor in the messianic lineage culminating in David, connecting Ruth’s son to this royal heritage (Ruth 4:12).

questions.question: What cultural significance does the public setting of the city gate in Ruth 4:1-2 hold for the redemption proceedings?
options: The city gate was the center of legal and civic authority where transactions were witnessed
It was the marketplace for buying and selling goods
It was a religious sanctuary for sacrifices
It was the private residence of the elders
questions.correctAnswer: The city gate was the center of legal and civic authority where transactions were witnessed
questions.explanation: In ancient Israel, the city gate was the place for legal matters and public decisions, making it the appropriate venue for Boaz’s redemption negotiation (Ruth 4:1-2).

theological.title: Ruth Chapter 4 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ruth Chapter 4 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What legal action does Boaz undertake at the city gate in Ruth 4?
options: He redeems the land and takes Ruth as his wife
He sells the land of Elimelech
He delivers a prophecy about David
He appoints elders over the city
questions.correctAnswer: He redeems the land and takes Ruth as his wife
questions.explanation: Boaz goes to the gate, calls the kinsman-redeemer, and legally redeems the land of Elimelech and takes Ruth as his wife, fulfilling the role of redeemer (Ruth 4:1-10). This act reflects the biblical principle of redemption and preservation of family inheritance (Lev 25:25, Deut 25:5, Gal 3:29, Romans 8:21).

questions.question: What role do the ten elders play in the transaction described in Ruth 4?
options: They serve as legal witnesses to the redemption
They decide who will marry Ruth
They determine the price of the land
questions.correctAnswer: They serve as legal witnesses to the redemption
questions.explanation: The ten elders sit as authoritative witnesses to the redemption of the land and Ruth, confirming the legality and communal recognition of the transaction (Ruth 4:2, 4:9-11). Witnesses are essential for legal and covenantal acts in the Old Testament (Deut 19:15, 2 Cor 13:1, Heb 12:1).

questions.question: Why does the nearer kinsman refuse to redeem the land and marry Ruth according to Ruth 4?
options: He fears it will harm his own inheritance
He does not want to marry a Moabite
He is not interested in the land
questions.correctAnswer: He fears it will harm his own inheritance
questions.explanation: The nearer kinsman declines to redeem the land because he says it may impair his own inheritance, thus passing the right to Boaz (Ruth 4:6). This reflects the biblical principle of protecting family inheritance while also allowing for the preservation of a deceased relative’s name (Deut 25:5-6, Num 27:8-11, 1 Cor 7:39).

questions.question: What symbolic act confirms the redemption transaction in Ruth 4?
options: The removal and transfer of a shoe
questions.correctAnswer: The removal and transfer of a shoe
questions.explanation: The removal of a shoe and its transfer to another person was the customary legal symbol confirming the transfer of redemption rights in Israel (Ruth 4:7-8). This act is unique to Israel’s legal customs and symbolizes the seriousness of covenantal agreements (Deut 25:9, Joshua 2:6, Hebrews 10:22).

questions.question: What is Boaz’s stated purpose in marrying Ruth, the Moabitess?
options: To raise up the name of the dead upon his inheritance
To forge an alliance with Moab
questions.correctAnswer: To raise up the name of the dead upon his inheritance
questions.explanation: Boaz declares he will marry Ruth to raise up the name of Mahlon, the dead husband, to preserve his family line and inheritance (Ruth 4:5, 4:10). This aligns with Levirate marriage laws and the biblical theme of God preserving His people’s lineage (Deut 25:5-10, Genesis 38:6-11, Matthew 1:5-6).

questions.question: Who are the witnesses to Boaz’s redemption and marriage to Ruth in Ruth 4?
options: The elders and all the people at the gate
questions.correctAnswer: The elders and all the people at the gate
questions.explanation: Boaz calls the elders and all the people at the gate to be witnesses of his redemption of the land and marriage to Ruth, ensuring public acknowledgment and legitimacy (Ruth 4:9-11). Public witnessing was crucial in ancient Israel for legal and covenantal matters (Deut 19:15, Neh 5:5, John 18:37).

questions.question: What blessings do the people invoke upon Boaz and Ruth when they become husband and wife?
options: That Ruth be like Rachel and Leah, who built the house of Israel
That Boaz become king of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: That Ruth be like Rachel and Leah, who built the house of Israel
questions.explanation: The people bless Ruth by comparing her to Rachel and Leah, matriarchs who built the house of Israel, thus recognizing her role in God's redemptive plan (Ruth 4:11). This blessing foreshadows the messianic line through David and ultimately Christ (Genesis 29:31-35, Matthew 1:3).

questions.question: What is the significance of the child born to Boaz and Ruth?
options: He is the grandfather of King David
He inherits the throne of Israel
He leads the people into exile
questions.correctAnswer: He is the grandfather of King David
questions.explanation: The child Obed, born to Boaz and Ruth, is the grandfather of King David, a key figure in God's messianic covenant (Ruth 4:17, 4:22). This lineage confirms God's providential plan in the grand narrative (2 Samuel 7:12-16, Isaiah 11:1, Luke 3:31).

questions.question: How does Naomi respond to the birth of Obed, and what theological theme does this express?
options: She takes the child and becomes his nurse, expressing restoration and hope
She names the child herself, showing human initiative
She rejects the child, symbolizing judgment
She offers the child as a sacrifice, demonstrating covenant obedience
questions.correctAnswer: She takes the child and becomes his nurse, expressing restoration and hope
questions.explanation: Naomi takes the child Obed into her care, symbolizing restoration of life and hope in old age (Ruth 4:16). This reflects God's providential care and restoration of His people (Psalm 71:9, Isaiah 46:4, 2 Corinthians 1:3-4).

questions.question: Which Old Testament practice is confirmed by the shoe removal in Ruth 4, and what does it symbolize?
options: Confirming legal transactions and the transfer of redemption rights
questions.correctAnswer: Confirming legal transactions and the transfer of redemption rights
questions.explanation: The removal of the shoe confirms the legal transfer of redemption rights, a custom unique to Israel, symbolizing binding covenantal agreement (Ruth 4:7-8, Deut 25:9-10). This act underscores the seriousness of God-ordained covenants (Jeremiah 32:7-9, Romans 7:2-3).

questions.question: In Ruth 4, what theological truth is demonstrated by Boaz agreeing to redeem both the land and Ruth?
options: God’s redemptive plan includes both people and property
Only land can be redeemed, not people
Redemption is only a financial transaction
questions.correctAnswer: God’s redemptive plan includes both people and property
questions.explanation: Boaz’s redemption of both land and Ruth illustrates God's comprehensive redemption that restores both possessions and relationships, revealing Christ as Redeemer of all creation (Ruth 4:4-5, Isaiah 49:8, Galatians 4:4-5, Ephesians 1:7).

questions.question: Which family line is traced through the genealogy in Ruth 4, and why is it significant?
options: The Davidic line, highlighting the messianic ancestry
questions.correctAnswer: The Davidic line, highlighting the messianic ancestry
questions.explanation: The genealogy traces the lineage from Pharez to David, emphasizing the messianic line culminating in Christ (Ruth 4:18-22, 2 Samuel 7:12-16, Matthew 1:1-16). This shows the continuity of God’s covenant promises.

questions.question: What does the public nature of the redemption at the city gate teach about God’s covenantal dealings with humanity?
options: Covenantal acts require open witnesses and communal acknowledgment
God’s covenants are hidden and secret
questions.correctAnswer: Covenantal acts require open witnesses and communal acknowledgment
questions.explanation: The public transaction at the gate with elders and people as witnesses shows that God’s covenants are established openly and communally, affirming accountability and order (Ruth 4:1-11, Deut 19:15, Hebrews 10:25, 2 Corinthians 6:14).

questions.question: How does the story of Ruth 4 contribute to the biblical doctrine of salvation history?
options: By showing God’s providential preservation of a messianic line through humble means
By emphasizing the need for military conquest
By promoting self-reliance over divine intervention
questions.correctAnswer: By showing God’s providential preservation of a messianic line through humble means
questions.explanation: Ruth 4 reveals God's providence in preserving the messianic line through a Gentile bride and a faithful redeemer, illustrating salvation history’s theme of God working through unexpected circumstances (Ruth 4:13-17, Genesis 12:3, Isaiah 11:1, Romans 9:10-13).

questions.question: What characteristic of God is revealed in His actions through Boaz in Ruth 4?
options: God’s faithfulness to covenant promises and redemption
questions.correctAnswer: God’s faithfulness to covenant promises and redemption
questions.explanation: Through Boaz’s redemption of Ruth and the land, God’s faithfulness to His covenant promises and His redemptive nature are revealed, showing His commitment to restore and bless His people (Ruth 4:10, Psalm 89:34, Lamentations 3:22-23, Hebrews 6:13-18).

questions.question: What does the role of Ruth, a Moabitess, in this chapter teach about God’s kingdom purposes?
options: God’s kingdom includes Gentiles and fulfills His promise through them
Only Israelites are part of God’s covenant
God’s promises are limited to one ethnic group
questions.correctAnswer: God’s kingdom includes Gentiles and fulfills His promise through them
questions.explanation: Ruth, a Moabitess, is included in the messianic line, demonstrating God’s inclusive plan of salvation that extends to Gentiles (Ruth 4:10, Isaiah 56:6-8, Galatians 3:28, Ephesians 2:11-22).
